<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of consumer_thread:
```c
static void *consumer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (!counter)
		metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock);
	counter--;
	metal_condition_signal(&nfull_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function consumer_thread:
int metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv,
				       metal_mutex_t *m)
{
	uintptr_t tmpmptr = 0, mptr = (uintptr_t)m;
	int v = 0;

	/* Check if the mutex has been acquired */
	if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m))
		return -EINVAL;

	if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) {
		if (tmpmptr != mptr)
			return -EINVAL;
	}

	v = atomic_load(&cv->wakeups);
	atomic_fetch_add(&cv->waiters, 1);

	/* Release the mutex before sleeping. */
	metal_mutex_release(m);
	syscall(SYS_futex, &cv->wakeups, FUTEX_WAIT, v, NULL, NULL, 0);
	atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
	/* Acquire the mutex after it's waken up. */
	metal_mutex_acquire(m);

	return 0;
}
...
METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE(lock)
...
static struct metal_condition nempty_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static struct metal_condition nfull_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static unsigned int counter
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock) does not invoke any <string.h> functions and neither the call site nor the provided metal_condition_wait implementation uses memcpy/strcpy/etc. The arguments are addresses of statically-initialized condition and mutex objects, so there is no risk of buffer accesses beyond object bounds from the string handling API. Therefore Rule 21.17 is not violated.
